facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 144 of 1960 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 144 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated July 26, 1957 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Civil Revision No. 966 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 26, 1957, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Civil Revision No. 966 of 1955.

facts.text: Arbitration agreement filed in court under s. 20 of the Arbitration Act, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: In this case an arbitration agreement had been filed in companyrt under s. 20 of the Arbitration Act, 1940, and an order of reference made thereon.

facts.text: Order of reference made on the arbitration agreement.

anchor.surface_text: In this case an arbitration agreement had been filed in companyrt under s. 20 of the Arbitration Act, 1940, and an order of reference made thereon.

facts.text: Arbitrator entered upon the reference.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrator in due companyrse entered upon the reference and made and filed his award in companyrt on July 14, 1955.

facts.text: Arbitrator made and filed his award in court on July 14, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrator in due companyrse entered upon the reference and made and filed his award in companyrt on July 14, 1955.

facts.text: Award concerned partition of certain properties between the wife and children of one Bhairon Bux.

anchor.surface_text: The award companycerned partition of certain properties between the wife and children of one Bhairon Bux.

facts.text: Award was unstamped and unregistered.

anchor.surface_text: The award was however unstamped and unregistered.

facts.text: Objection taken to judgment being passed on the unstamped and unregistered award.

anchor.surface_text: An objection was taken to a judgment being passed on such an award.

facts.text: Trial court passed order remitting award to arbitrator for re-submitting on duly stamped paper and after getting it registered.

anchor.surface_text: On such objection, the trial companyrt passed an order remitting the award to the arbitrator for re-submitting it to the companyrt on a duly stamped paper and after getting it registered.

facts.text: Revision filed against trial court order in High Court at Nagpur in Civil Revision No. 966 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order the High Court at Nagpur was moved in revision.

facts.text: Single Judge held award required stamping but could not be remitted under s.16.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Single Judge hearing the revision application took the view that the award required to be stamped. But he felt that it companyld number be remitted to the arbitrator under s. 16 of the Arbitration Act

facts.text: Single Judge referred three questions to larger bench.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Single Judge was apparently number satisfied with the companyrectness of the decision in Ramkumars case  1  and he referred three questions for decision by a larger bench of that High Court.

facts.text: Three questions referred: (1) Is award under s.20 chargeable to stamp duty? (2) Compulsorily registerable for partition of immovable property value Rs.100+? (3) Court power under s.16(1)(c) to remit for stamping/registration?

anchor.surface_text: The questions referred were Is the award made on a reference by the Court on an application under section 20 of the Arbitration Act chargeable to stamp duty? Is such an award companypulsorily registerable when it relates to partition of immovable property of the value of one hundred rupees and upwards? Has the Court powers under section 16 1   c  of the Arbitration Act of 1940 or otherwise to remit an award to the arbitrator or umpire to get it stamped and or registered?

facts.text: Division Bench heard the matter.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was thereupon heard by a Division Bench of the High Court companystituted by two learned Judges.

facts.text: Both parties agreed before Division Bench that award required stamping.

anchor.surface_text: Before them it was agreed by both the parties that the award required to be stamped. This disposed of the first question.

facts.text: Division Bench did not answer second question on registration.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges felt that it was number necessary at that stage of the proceeding to answer the second question, namely, whether the award required registration.

facts.text: Division Bench answered third question affirmatively: court can remit under s.16(1)(c) for stamping.

anchor.surface_text: In the result they only answered the third question as to whether an award companyld be remitted under s. 16  1   c  of the Arbitration Act to the arbitrator to get it stamped and they answered that question in the affirmative.

facts.text: Division Bench held want of stamp is illegality apparent on face, falls under s.16(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: They held that a want of stamp would be an illegality apparent on the face of the award and therefore the case would fall under s. 16 1  c  of the Arbitration Act.

facts.text: Present appeal against Division Bench judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal is against this judgment of the Division Bench.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Division Bench erred; award cannot be remitted under s.16 for re-writing on stamped paper as it is not for reconsideration.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the Division Bench of the High Court was clearly in error. Under s. 16 of the Arbitration Act an award can be remitted to the arbitrators only for reconsideration. When it is remitted for re-writing it on a stamped paper, it is number remitted for reconsideration.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and set aside orders of courts below remitting the award.

anchor.surface_text: In the result this appeal is allowed. The orders of the Courts below remitting the award are set aside.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on November 16, 1961 by SARKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. November 16. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR, J.

issues.text: Is the award made on a reference by the Court on an application under section 20 of the Arbitration Act chargeable to stamp duty?

issues.text: Has the Court powers under section 16(1)(c) of the Arbitration Act of 1940 or otherwise to remit an award to the arbitrator or umpire to get it stamped and or registered?

anchor.surface_text: Has the Court powers under section 16 1   c  of the Arbitration Act of 1940 or otherwise to remit an award to the arbitrator or umpire to get it stamped and or registered?

issues.text: Does remitting an unstamped award to the arbitrator for re-writing it on stamped paper constitute remittal for reconsideration under section 16 of the Arbitration Act?

anchor.surface_text: We think that the Division Bench of the High Court was clearly in error. Under s. 16 of the Arbitration Act an award can be remitted to the arbitrators only for reconsideration. When it is remitted for re-writing it on a stamped paper, it is number remitted for reconsideration.

issues.text: Can the court order the arbitrator to re-write the unstamped award on stamped paper under section 14(1) of the Arbitration Act based on the duty to inform fees and charges?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak appearing for the respondent contended that under s. 14 1 of the Arbitration Act it was clearly the duty of the arbitrator to inform the parties of the amount of stamp duty payable on the award. Section 14 1 is in these terms Section 14 1 When the arbitrators or umpire have made their award,

issues.text: Can the order remitting the award for stamping be supported under section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure using inherent powers?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak contended that even if the case did number come within s. 16 1   c  of the Arbitration Act, the order in the present case can be supported under s. 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure which preserves the inherent power of a court to make such orders as may be necessary for the ends of justice.

issues.text: Is the arbitrator functus officio after signing the award, preventing re-writing or remedying defects like lack of stamping?

anchor.surface_text: But it is well known that after making his award the arbitrator is functus officio. To cite one authority for this proposition we may quote the observations of Mellish, L. J., in Mordue v. Palmer 1 . I think the result of the cases at law is that when an arbitrator has signed a document as and for his award, he is functus officio,

arguments.claim: Under s.16, remittal only for reconsideration; re-writing on stamped paper not reconsideration

anchor.surface_text: We think that the Division Bench of the High Court was clearly in error. Under s. 16 of the Arbitration Act an award can be remitted to the arbitrators only for reconsideration. When it is remitted for re-writing it on a stamped paper, it is not remitted for reconsideration.

arguments.claim: Want of stamp/registration is defect dehors the award, not covered by s.16(1)(c)

anchor.surface_text: Reconsideration by the arbitrators necessarily imports fresh consideration of matters already considered by them... We think the matter was correctly put by Mitter, J., in Nani Bala Saha v. Ram Gopal Saha 1 ... Want of registration is a defect dehors the award or the decision of the arbitrator, and so in our judgment is not covered by cl. c of S. 16 1 , Arbitration Act of 1940.

arguments.claim: Arbitrator functus officio after making and signing award; cannot remedy mistake or re-write

anchor.surface_text: But it is well known that after making his award the arbitrator is functus officio. To cite one authority for this proposition we may quote the observations of Mellish, L. J., in Mordue v. Palmer 1 . I think the result of the cases at law is that when an arbitrator has signed a document as and for his award, he is functus officio,

holdings.text: Under s. 16 of the Arbitration Act an award can be remitted to the arbitrators only for reconsideration. When it is remitted for re-writing it on a stamped paper, it is not remitted for reconsideration.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the Division Bench of the High Court was clearly in error. Under s. 16 of the Arbitration Act an award can be remitted to the arbitrators only for reconsideration. When it is remitted for re-writing it on a stamped paper, it is not remitted for

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 16(1)(c) permits remittal only where objection to legality apparent on face, for reconsideration of merits involving fresh consideration of referred matters; re-writing on stamped paper is ministerial act, not reconsideration.

holdings.text: Want of stamp is a defect dehors the award, not an illegality apparent on the face of it under s.16(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: Reconsideration by the arbitrators necessarily imports fresh consideration of matters already considered by them... We think the matter was correctly put by Mitter, J., in Nani Bala Saha v. Ram Gopal Saha 1 ... Want of registration is a defect

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Nani Bala Saha, lack of stamp/registration is external defect not part of award's content or reasoning, unlike errors of law on face; applies equally to stamping as registration.

holdings.text: Section 14(1) of the Arbitration Act does not justify remitting award to arbitrator to inscribe it afresh on stamped paper.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to see how this section can provide the basis for the order made in this case. It only says that the arbitrators shall inform the parties of the fees and charges payable. Even assuming that the word charges includes duty payable

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.14(1) requires only notice of making award and fees/charges; even if charges include stamp duty, supports only directing information, not re-submission on stamped paper; stamping due at execution per Stamp Act s.17.

holdings.text: Court cannot support remittal order under s.151 CPC inherent powers as arbitrator is functus officio after award.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak contended that even if the case did not come within s. 16(1)(c) of the Arbitration Act, the order in the present case can be supported under s. 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure which preserves the inherent power of a court

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.41 applies CPC to arbitration proceedings but s.151 cannot override functus officio doctrine; directing functus arbitrator to make fresh stamped copy violates arbitration principles; copy not original award.

holdings.text: Arbitrator is functus officio upon signing award and cannot remedy defects like lack of stamping or re-write award.

anchor.surface_text: But it is well known that after making his award the arbitrator is functus officio. To cite one authority for this proposition we may quote the observations of Mellish, L. J., in Mordue v. Palmer 1 . I think the result of the cases at

holdings.reasoning_summary: Established doctrine post Mordue v. Palmer: signing award exhausts authority; cannot unilaterally remedy mistakes or produce new version.

holdings.text: Order remitting for stamping cannot be based on ss.13(d) or 15 of Arbitration Act.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, Mr. Pathak tried to support the order under ss. 13(d) and 15(b) and (c) of the Arbitration Act. A bare perusal of the provisions mentioned would show that the order made in this case cannot be based on any of them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.13(d) enables correction of clerical slips (unstamped not such); discretionary, not compulsory. s.15 for court modification/correction, not invoked here.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that there was an earlier judgment of the Nagpur High Court in the case of Ramkumar v. Kushalchand 1 in which it had been held that where the award was unstamped it could under paragraph 14 of Schedule I to the Code of Civil Procedure be remitted to the arbitrator with a direction to re-write it on a stamped paper and re-submit it to companyrt.

precedents.cited_proposition: unstamped award could be remitted to arbitrator under paragraph 14 of Schedule I to CPC to rewrite on stamped paper and resubmit

anchor.surface_text: They also held, following the case of Lakhmichand v. Kalloolal 1 , that the copying of the award on a stamped paper was purely ministerial, and making of an award did number deprive the arbitrator of the authority to companyy an award on the requisite stamp paper.

precedents.cited_proposition: copying of the award on a stamped paper was purely ministerial and making of an award did not deprive the arbitrator of the authority to copy an award on the requisite stamp paper

precedents.citation: Nani Bala Saha v. Ram Gopal Saha 1

anchor.surface_text: We think the matter was companyrectly put by Mitter, J., in Nani Bala Saha v. Ram Gopal Saha 1 in the following observation That cl. c means this and numberhing more namely, that where the companyrt finds an error of law in the award itself or in some document actually incorporated thereto on which the arbitrator had based his award, that is to say, finds the statement of some erroneous legal proposition which is the basis of the award, it can remit the award to the arbitrator for reconsideration and

precedents.case_name: Nani Bala Saha v. Ram Gopal Saha
precedents.cited_proposition: s.16(1)(c) applies only where error of law apparent on face of award; want of stamp or registration is defect dehors the award not covered by cl.(c)
precedents.cited_holding: That cl. c means this and numberhing more namely, that where the companyrt finds an error of law in the award itself or in some document actually incorporated thereto on which the arbitrator had based his award, that is to say, finds the statement of some erroneous legal proposition which is the basis of the award, it can remit the award to the arbitrator for reconsideration and Want of registration is a defect dehors the award or the decision of the arbitrator, and so in our judgment is number companyered by cl. c of S. 16 1 , Arbitration Act of 1940.

anchor.surface_text: To cite one authority for this proposition we may quote the observations of Mellish, L. J., in Mordue v. Palmer 1 . I think the result of the cases at law is that when an arbitrator has signed a document as and for his award, he is functus officio, and he cannot of his own authority remedy any mistake.

precedents.cited_proposition: arbitrator functus officio after signing the award and cannot remedy any mistake
precedents.cited_holding: I think the result of the cases at law is that when an arbitrator has signed a document as and for his award, he is functus officio, and he cannot of his own authority remedy any mistake.

anchor.surface_text: In the result this appeal is allowed. The orders of the Courts below remitting the award are set aside. The appellant will get the costs throughout.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; orders of the courts below remitting the award set aside

anchor.surface_text: We think that the Division Bench of the High Court was clearly in error. Under s. 16 of the Arbitration Act an award can be remitted to the arbitrators only for reconsideration. When it is remitted for re-writing it on a stamped paper, it is not remitted for
In the result this appeal is allowed. The orders of the Courts below remitting the award are set aside. The appellant will get the costs throughout.
